frontmatter.title: Write query resolvers
frontmatter.description: Learn how a GraphQL query fetches data

children.value: We've designed our schema and configured our data sources, but our server doesn't know how to
its data sources to populate schema fields. To solve this, we'll define a collection of resolvers.
A resolver is a function that's responsible for populating the data for a single field in your schema.
Whenever a client queries for a particular field, the resolver for that field fetches the requested data from the appropriate data source.
A resolver function returns one of the following:
Data of the type required by the resolver's corresponding schema field (string, integer, object, etc.)
A promise that fulfills with data of the required type
Before we start writing resolvers, let's cover what a resolver function's signature looks like. Resolver functions can optionally accept four positional arguments:
This is the return value of the resolver for this field's parent (the resolver for a parent field always executes
the resolvers for that field's children).
This object is shared across all resolvers that execute for a particular operation. Use this to share per-operation state, such as authentication information and access to data sources.
This contains information about the execution state of the operation (used only in advanced cases).
Of these four arguments, the resolvers we define will mostly use
. It enables our resolvers to share instances of our
data sources. To see how that works, let's get started creating some resolvers.

As mentioned above, the resolver for a parent field always executes before the resolvers for that field's children. Therefore, let's start by defining resolvers for some top-level fields: the fields of the
. To define resolvers for these fields, open
As this code shows, we define our resolvers in a
, where the map's keys correspond to our schema's types (
All three resolver functions assign their first
as a convention to indicate that they don't use its value.
). Specifically, they destructure it to access the
None of the resolver functions includes the fourth positional argument (
), because they don't use it and there's no other need to include it.
As you can see, these resolver functions are short! That's possible because most of the logic they rely on is part of the
data sources. By keeping resolvers thin as a best practice, you can safely refactor your backing logic while reducing the likelihood of breaking your API.

properties.ariaLabel: add resolvers to apollo server permalink

By providing your resolver map to Apollo Server like so, it knows how to call resolver functions as needed to fulfill incoming queries.
Let's run a test query on our server! Start it up with

Paste the following query into the tool's editor panel:
# We'll cover more about the structure of a query later in the tutorial.

Then, click the Run button. Our server's response appears on the right. See how the structure of the response object matches the structure of the query? This correspondence is a fundamental feature of GraphQL.

You might have noticed that the
we ran above included several fields that we haven't even written resolvers for. But somehow those queries still ran successfully! That's because Apollo Server defines a
for any field you don't define a custom resolver for.

You might be wondering how our server knows the identity of the current user when calling functions like
. It doesn't yet! We'll fix that in the next chapter.
objects. This is often more information than a client needs at once, and fetching that much data can be slow. We can improve this field's performance by implementing
Pagination ensures that our server sends data in small chunks. We recommend

for numbered pages, because it eliminates the possibility of skipping an item or displaying the same item more than once. In cursor-based pagination, a constant pointer (or cursor) is used to keep track of where to start in the data set when fetching the next set of results.
Let's set up cursor-based pagination. In
to match the following, and also add a new type called
# replace the current launches query with this one.
The number of results to show. Must be >= 1. Default = 20
If you add a cursor here, it will only return results _after_ this cursor
Simple wrapper around our list of launches that contains a cursor to the
last item in the list. Pass this cursor to the launches query to fetch results
# add this below the Query type as an additional type.
(the actual data requested by a query)
that indicates the current position in the data set
boolean that indicates whether the data set contains any more items beyond those included in
function. This is a helper function for paginating data from the server.
Now, let's update the necessary resolver functions to accommodate pagination. Import
// we want these in reverse chronological order
// if the cursor at the end of the paginated results is the same as the
// last item in _all_ results, then there are no more results after this
Let's test the cursor-based pagination we just implemented. Restart your server with
and run this query in the Explorer/GraphQL Playground:
Thanks to our pagination implementation, the server should only return three launches instead of the full list.
